reviewText: I have viewed all seasons of AS TIME GOES BY on numerous occasions. The comedy and relationship issues are subtle, yet realistic and, at times, poignant. It is a shame that American television cannot produce high quality family programming such as this.The only complaint that I have is that Closed Captioning is not available. As I grow older, I find that I need this option with greater frequency, especially with shows which have actors who have foreign accents.By the way, your readers may like to know that they can watch the 2-part reunion special (without cost) on YOU TUBE. Said episode is not apparently available on Amazon Prime.

reviewText: This is just a fabulously entertaining television series -- funny and sweet. Although the seasons are short compared to US Shows (This set has 7 episodes), they're enjoyable enough that they're worth it. (Great things come in small packages.) Here's a quick summary of the episodes:1. Jean suspects Lionel is going deaf, but he resists going to the doctor. Meanwhile, Lionel becomes convinced that Jean is having problems with her eyes.2. Jean & Lionel take a parental interest in Harry, Sandy's policeman boyfriend. Yet the affairs of the younger generation seem to diminish in importance when Jean receives a phone message from an old flame.3. Jean undertakes some strategic snooping to discover what the new neighbors are like. How is it they show up at the pub with black eyes?4. The whole gang heads out to the country for the weekend. But road construction is about to throw the travelers for a loop.5. Jean's brother, Stephen, and his wife are expected for another visit. To the Hardcastles' surprise, they arrive via separate modes of transportation to announce that they are having a tiff.6. Jean gets everyone, including Lionel's father and stepmother, to help out with her old-age party at the church hall. Lionel is anxious about the whole idea, especially after being told to watch out for Mrs. Thrupp.7. The Duncans abruptly vacate the dwelling next door, and Judith has the wonderful idea that she and Alistair move in. Lionel has his reservations, but they are nothing compared to the reservations of Judith when Alistair makes a surprising proposal.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An English couple reunite accidentally in London after 38 years. Jean, a widow running her own temp secretarial agency; her twice-divorced grown daughter still living at home; and Lionel, an irascible retired coffee plantation grower from Kenya, divorced, with no children. In addition to these characters, there's an over-the-top suitor for the daughter who is also the publisher of Lionel's memoirs; Lionel's lively globe trotting 80 year old father and his new wife; a winsome employee of Jean's agency and her beau; Jean's former sister-in-law and her dentist husband, two annoying but very funny characters; and the housekeeper and groundskeeper who maintain Lionel's father's country estate, both zany but endearing. Although the canned laughter is interruptive, the situations these characters find themselves in and the entanglements that result from their actions are very human and often hilarious.  And, of course, Judy Dench steals the show.
summary: It's Never too Late for Love

reviewText: This is the last of the ATGB series and I truly hate to see it end.  It was one of the best comedy series ever produced by the BBC and is so classy that, in the light of the usual "racy" Brit comedy fare, I am amazed that it ever got produced at all.  The fact that the series became so truly popular on both sides of the Atlantic is a tribute to viewer's good taste and (dare I say?) boredom with raunchy TV shows. The laughs are gentle, though often sophisticated without being off-color, and the characters are superbly portrayed by excellent actors.  Of course, the star is the incomparable Judi but the supporting cast, especially the late, lamented Frank Middlemass as Rocky, are wonderful also.  I am just grateful that it is available to view over and over - I call it my "Brit Comfort Comedy."
summary: One of the best of the Brit series

reviewText: Series 7Episode 1 - Jean thinks that Lionel is going deaf and Lionel thinks Jean's sight is failing.  Neither one wants to admit their own problem.Episode 2 - Jean receives a message from an old romantic flame.  When she meets up with him he has not only lost is dashing figure but is a drunk.Episode 3 - The new neighbors arrive and Jean tries to find out everything about them.  But all regret meeting them.Episode 4 - The entire gang goes to the country.  When the locals are up in arms over a new bypass, Jean decides to head up the protest committee before she finds out what side the town is on.Episode 5 - Stephen and Penny are coming for another visit.  But when Penny arrives first, Jean and Lionel discover Penny and Stephen are having a tiff.  (And as expected a stupid one).Episode 6 - Jean gets the entire gang including Rocky and Madge, to help out with an event for the senior citizens.Episode 7 - When the new neigbors vacate, Judith thinks that Alister should buy it.  But things change when Alister wants more of a commitment then Judith is expecting.
